intro: Quercus suber subf. clavata, commonly known as the cork oak, is a member of the Fagaceae family and is native to the Iberian Peninsula. It is characterized by its thick, corky bark, which is harvested for commercial use. The plant has lance-shaped leaves that are typically covered in a dense layer of white, fuzzy hair. It produces small, acorn-like fruits that are an important food source for various wildlife. This subspecies is adapted to Mediterranean climates and thrives in well-drained, acidic soils.
